Text

ï»¿A Romance of Two Worlds

A NOVEL .

BY

[MARIE CORELLI]89-marie corelli , PROLOGUE .

[We]255-we live in an age of universal inquiry , ergo of universal scepticism . The prophecies of [the poet]256-the poet , the dreams of [the philosopher and scientist]257-the philosopher and scientist , are being daily realized - things formerly considered mere fairy - tales have become facts - yet , in spite of the marvels of learning and science that are hourly accomplished among [us]255-we , the attitude of [mankind]258-mankind is one of disbelief . " There is [no God]1729-no god ! "[259-one theorist] cries [one theorist]259-one theorist ; " or if there be one , [I]259-one theorist can obtain no proof of [His]1730-his existence ! "[259-one theorist] " There is [no Creator]1731-no creator ! "[261-another] exclaims another . " [The Universe]1-the universe is simply a rushing together of atoms . "[261-another] " There can be no immortality , "[260-a third] asserts [a third]260-a third . " [We]255-we are but dust , and to dust [we]255-we shall return . "[261-another] " What is called by [idealists the SOUL]1732-idealists the soul , "[261-another] argues [another]261-another , " is simply the vital principle composed of heat and air , which escapes from the body at death , and mingles again with its native element . A candle when lit emits flame ; blow out the light , the flame vanishes - where ? Would it not be madness to assert the flame immortal ? Yet the soul , or vital principle of human existence , is no more than the flame of a candle . "[261-another]

If [you]262-you propound to [these theorists]263-these theorists the eternal question WHY ? - why is [the world]264-the world in existence ? why is there [a universe]265-a universe ? why do [we]255-we live ? why do [we]255-we think and plan ? why do [we]255-we perish at the last ? - [their]263-these theorists grandiose reply is , " Because of the Law of Universal Necessity . "[263-these theorists] [They]263-these theorists can not explain this mysterious Law to [themselves]263-these theorists , nor can [they]263-these theorists probe deep enough to find the answer to a still more tremendous WHY - namely , WHY , is there a Law of Universal Necessity ? - but [they]263-these theorists are satisfied with the result of [their]263-these theorists reasonings , if not wholly , yet in part , and seldom try to search beyond that great vague vast Necessity , lest [their]263-these theorists finite brains should reel into madness worse than death . Recognizing , therefore , that in this cultivated age a wall of scepticism and cynicism is gradually being built up by [intellectual thinkers of [every nation]267-every nation]266-intellectual thinkers of every nation against all that treats of the Supernatural and Unseen , [I]0-i am aware that [my]0-i narration of the events [I]0-i have recently experienced will be read with incredulity . At a time when [the great empire of the Christian Religion]268-the great empire of the christian religion is being assailed , or politely ignored by [governments]269-governments and [public speakers]270-public speakers and [teachers]271-teachers , [I]0-i realize to the fullest extent how daring is any attempt to prove , even by a plain history of strange occurrences happening to [one]272-one 's self , the actual existence of the Supernatural around [us]255-we ; and the absolute certainty of a future state of being , after the passage through that brief soul - torpor in which the body perishes , known to [us]255-we as Death .

In the present narration , which [I]0-i have purposely called a " romance , "[0-i] [I]0-i do not expect to be believed , as [I]0-i can only relate what [I]0-i [myself]0-i have experienced . [I]0-i know that [men]273-men and [women of to - day]274-women of to - day must have proofs , or what [they]274-women of to - day are willing to accept as proofs , before [they]274-women of to - day will credit anything that purports to be of a spiritual tendency ; - something startling - some miracle of a stupendous nature , such as according to prophecy [they]274-women of to - day are all unfit to receive . [Few]275-few will admit the subtle influence and incontestable , though mysterious , authority exercised upon [their]275-few lives by higher intelligences than [their]275-few own - intelligences unseen , unknown , but felt . Yes ! felt by [the most careless]276-the most careless , the most cynical ; in the uncomfortable prescience of danger , the inner forebodings of guilt - the moral and mental torture endured by [those who fight a protracted battle to gain the hardly - won victory in themselves of right over wrong]277-those who fight a protracted battle to gain the hardly - won victory in themselves of right over wrong - in the thousand and one sudden appeals made without warning to that compass of [a man]278-a man 's life , Conscience - and in those brilliant and startling impulses of generosity , bravery , and self - sacrifice which carry [us]255-we on , heedless of consequences , to the performance of great and noble deeds , whose fame makes [the whole world]279-the whole world [one resounding echo of glory]280-one resounding echo of glory - deeds that [we]255-we wonder at [ourselves]255-we even in the performance of them - acts of heroism in which mere life goes for nothing , and the Soul for a brief space is pre - eminent , obeying blindly the guiding influence of a something akin to itself , yet higher in [the realms of Thought]281-the realms of thought .

There are no proofs as to why such things should be ; but that they are , is indubitable . The miracles enacted now are silent ones , and are worked in the heart and mind of [man]282-man alone . Unbelief is nearly supreme in [the world]264-the world to - day . Were [an angel]284-an angel to descend from heaven in the middle of [a great square]285-a great square , [the crowd]286-the crowd would think [he]284-an angel had got [himself]284-an angel up on pulleys and wires , and would try to discover [his]284-an angel apparatus . Were [he]284-an angel , in wrath , to cast destruction upon [them]286-the crowd , and with fire blazing from [his]284-an angel wings , slay a thousand of [them]286-the crowd with the mere shaking of a pinion , [those who were left alive]287-those who were left alive would either say that a tremendous dynamite explosion had occurred , or that [the square]288-the square was built on an extinct volcano which had suddenly broken out into frightful activity . Anything rather than believe in [angels]289-angels - the nineteenth century protests against the possibility of [their]289-angels existence . It sees no miracle - it pooh - poohs the very enthusiasm that might work [them]289-angels .

" Give a positive sign , "[289-angels] it says ; " prove clearly that what [you]1733-you say is true , and [I]289-angels , in spite of [my]289-angels Progress and Atom Theory , will believe . "[289-angels] The answer to such a request was spoken eighteen hundred years and more ago . " [A faithless and perverse generation]1734-a faithless and perverse generation asketh for a sign , and no sign shall be given unto [them]1734-a faithless and perverse generation . "[289-angels]

Were [I]0-i now to assert that a sign had been given to [ME]0-i - to [me]0-i , as one out of [the thousands who demand it]290-the thousands who demand it - such daring assurance on [my]0-i part would meet with the most strenuous opposition from [all who peruse the following pages]291-all who peruse the following pages ; [each person who reads having [his]292-each person who reads having his own ideas on all subjects own ideas on all subjects]292-each person who reads having his own ideas on all subjects , and naturally considering them to be the best if not the only ideas worth anything . Therefore [I]0-i wish it to be plainly understood that in this book [I]0-i personally advocate no new theory of either religion or philosophy ; nor do [I]0-i hold [myself]0-i answerable for the opinions expressed by any of [[my]0-i characters]293-my characters . [My]0-i aim throughout is to let facts speak for [themselves]294-themselves . If they seem strange , unreal , even impossible , [I]0-i can only say that the things of [the invisible world]295-the invisible world must always appear so to [those whose thoughts and desires are centred on this life]296-those whose thoughts and desires are centred on this life only .

CHAPTER I.

[AN ARTIST 'S STUDIO]297-an artist 's studio .

In the winter of 188- , [I]0-i was afflicted by a series of nervous ailments , brought on by overwork and overworry . Chief among these was a protracted and terrible insomnia , accompanied by the utmost depression of spirits and anxiety of mind . [I]0-i became filled with the gloomiest anticipations of evil ; and [my]0-i system was strung up by slow degrees to such a high tension of physical and mental excitement , that the quietest and most soothing of friendly voices had no other effect upon [me]0-i than to jar and irritate . Work was impossible ; music , [my]0-i one passion , intolerable ; books became wearisome to [my]0-i sight ; and even a short walk in the open air brought with it such lassitude and exhaustion , that [I]0-i soon grew to dislike the very thought of moving out of doors . In such a condition of health , medical aid became necessary ; and [a skilful and amiable physician]298-a skilful and amiable physician , [Dr. R - - , of great repute in nervous ailments]299-dr. r - - , of great repute in nervous ailments , attended [me]0-i for many weeks , with but slight success . [He]298-a skilful and amiable physician was not to blame , [poor man]300-poor man , for [his]298-a skilful and amiable physician failure to effect a cure . [He]298-a skilful and amiable physician had only one way of treatment , and [he]298-a skilful and amiable physician applied it to all [[his]298-a skilful and amiable physician patients]301-his patients with more or less happy results . [Some]302-some died , [some]302-some recovered ; it was a lottery on which [[my]0-i medical friend]304-my medical friend staked [his]298-a skilful and amiable physician reputation , and won . [The patients who died]305-the patients who died were never heard of more - those who recovered sang the praises of [[their]305-the patients who died physician]306-their physician everywhere , and sent [him]298-a skilful and amiable physician gifts of silver plate and hampers of wine , to testify [their]305-the patients who died gratitude . [His]298-a skilful and amiable physician popularity was very great ; [his]298-a skilful and amiable physician skill considered marvellous ; and [his]298-a skilful and amiable physician inability to do [ME]0-i any good arose , [I]0-i must perforce imagine , out of some defect or hidden obstinacy in [my]0-i constitution , which was to [him]298-a skilful and amiable physician a new experience , and for which [he]298-a skilful and amiable physician was unprepared . [Poor Dr. R]90-poor dr. r - - ! How many bottles of [your]307-your tastily prepared and expensive medicines have [I]0-i not swallowed , in blind confidence and blinder ignorance of the offences [I]0-i thus committed against all the principles of that Nature within [me]0-i , which , if left to itself , always heroically struggles to recover its own proper balance and effect its own cure ; but which , if subjected to the experimental tests of various poisons or drugs , often loses strength in the unnatural contest and sinks exhausted , perhaps never to rise with actual vigour again . [Baffled]91-baffled in [his]298-a skilful and amiable physician attempts to remedy [my]0-i ailments , [Dr. R]90-poor dr. r - - at last resorted to the usual plan adopted by [all physicians]308-all physicians when [their]308-all physicians medicines have no power . [He]298-a skilful and amiable physician recommended change of air and scene , and urged [my]0-i leaving [London]2-london , then dark with the fogs of a dreary winter , for the gaiety and sunshine and roses of [the Riviera]3-the riviera . The idea was not unpleasant to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i determined to take the advice proffered . Hearing of [my]0-i intention , [some American friends of [mine]0-i]309-some american friends of mine , [Colonel Everard]92-colonel everard and [[his]92-colonel everard charming young wife]310-his charming young wife , decided to accompany [me]0-i , sharing with [me]0-i the expenses of the journey and [hotel accommodation]311-hotel accommodation . [We]312-we left [London]2-london all together on a damp foggy evening , when the cold was so intense that it seemed to bite the flesh like the sharp teeth of an animal , and after two days ' rapid journey , during which [I]0-i felt [my]0-i spirits gradually rising , and [my]0-i gloomy forebodings vanishing slowly one by one , [we]312-we arrived at [Cannes]4-cannes , and put up at [the Hotel de L - -]313-the hotel de l - - . [It]313-the hotel de l - - was [a lovely place]314-a lovely place , and most beautifully situated ; [the garden]315-the garden was [a perfect wilderness of roses]316-a perfect wilderness of roses in full bloom , and an avenue of orange - trees beginning to flower cast a delicate fragrance on the warm delicious air .

[Mrs. Everard]93-amy was delighted .

" If [you]0-i do not recover [your]0-i health here , "[93-amy] [she]93-amy said half laughingly to [me]0-i on the second morning after [our]312-we arrival , " [I]93-amy am afraid [your]0-i case is hopeless . What sunshine ! What a balmy wind ! It is enough to make [a cripple]1735-a cripple cast away [his]1735-a cripple crutches and forget [he]1735-a cripple was ever lame . Do n't [you]0-i think so ? "[93-amy]

[I]0-i smiled in answer , but inwardly [I]0-i sighed . Beautiful as the scenery , the air , and the general surroundings were , [I]0-i could not disguise from [myself]0-i that the temporary exhilaration of [my]0-i feelings , caused by the novelty and excitement of [my]0-i journey to [Cannes]4-cannes , was slowly but surely passing away . The terrible apathy , against which [I]0-i had fought for so many months , was again creeping over [me]0-i with its cruel and resistless force . [I]0-i did [my]0-i best to struggle against it ; [I]0-i walked , [I]0-i rode , [I]0-i laughed and chatted with [Mrs. Everard]93-amy and [[her]93-amy husband]317-her husband , and forced [myself]0-i into sociability with [some of [the visitors at [the hotel]320-the hotel , who were disposed to show [us]321-us friendly attention]319-the visitors at the hotel , who were disposed to show us friendly attention]318-some of the visitors at the hotel , who were disposed to show us friendly attention . [I]0-i summoned all [my]0-i stock of will - power to beat back the insidious physical and mental misery that threatened to sap the very spring of [my]0-i life ; and in some of these efforts [I]0-i partially succeeded . But it was at night that the terrors of [my]0-i condition manifested themselves . Then sleep forsook [my]0-i eyes ; a dull throbbing weight of pain encircled [my]0-i head like a crown of thorns ; nervous terrors shook [me]0-i from head to foot ; fragments of [my]0-i own musical compositions hummed in [my]0-i ears with wearying persistence - fragments that always left [me]0-i in a state of distressed conjecture ; for [I]0-i never could remember how they ended , and [I]0-i puzzled [myself]0-i vainly over crotchets and quavers that never would consent to arrange themselves in any sort of finale . So the days went on ; for [Colonel Everard]92-colonel everard and [[his]92-colonel everard wife]322-his wife , those days were full of merriment , sight - seeing , and enjoyment . For [me]0-i , though outwardly [I]0-i appeared to share in the universal gaiety , they were laden with increasing despair and wretchedness ; for [I]0-i began to lose hope of ever recovering [my]0-i once buoyant health and strength , and , what was even worse , [I]0-i seemed to have utterly parted with all working ability . [I]0-i was young , and up to within a few months life had stretched brightly before [me]0-i , with the prospect of a brilliant career . And now what was [I]0-i ? [A wretched invalid]323-a wretched invalid - a burden to [myself]0-i and to [others]324-others - a broken spar flung with other fragments of ship wrecked lives on [the great ocean of Time]325-the great ocean of time , there to be whirled away and forgotten . But a rescue was approaching ; a rescue sudden and marvellous , of which , in [my]0-i wildest fancies , [I]0-i had never dreamed .

Staying in [the same hotel]326-the same hotel with [us]327-us was [a young Italian artist , [Raffaello Cellini]97-cellini by name]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name . [His]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name pictures were beginning to attract a great deal of notice , both in [Paris]5-paris and [Rome]6-rome : not only for [their]329-their faultless drawing , but for their wonderfully exquisite colouring . So deep and warm and rich were the hues [he]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name transferred to [his]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name canvases , that [others of [his]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name art]330-others of his art , less fortunate in the management of the palette , declared [he]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name must have invented some foreign compound whereby [he]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name was enabled to deepen and brighten [his]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name colours for the time being ; but that the effect was only temporary , and that [his]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name pictures , exposed to the air for some eight or ten years , would fade away rapidly , leaving only the traces of an indistinct blur . [Others]324-others , more generous , congratulated [him]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name on having discovered the secrets of [the old masters]332-the old masters . In short , [he]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name was admired , condemned , envied , and flattered , all in a breath ; while [he]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name [himself]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name , being of a singularly serene and unruffled disposition , worked away incessantly , caring little or nothing for [the world]264-the world 's praise or blame .

[Cellini]97-cellini had [a pretty suite of rooms in [the Hotel de L - -]313-the hotel de l - -]334-a pretty suite of rooms in the hotel de l - - , and [[my]0-i friends]336-my friends [Colonel]92-colonel everard and [Mrs. Everard]93-amy fraternized with [him]328-a young italian artist , raffaello cellini by name very warmly . [He]97-cellini was by no means slow to respond to [their]336-my friends overtures of friendship , and so it happened that [[his]97-cellini studio]337-his studio became [a sort of lounge for [us]339-us , where [we]339-us would meet to have tea , to chat , to look at the pictures , or to discuss [our]339-us plans for future enjoyment]338-a sort of lounge for us , where we would meet to have tea , to chat , to look at the pictures , or to discuss our plans for future enjoyment . These visits to [[Cellini]97-cellini 's studio]340-cellini 's studio , strange to say , had a remarkably soothing and calming effect upon [my]0-i suffering nerves . [The lofty and elegant room]341-the lofty and elegant room , furnished with that " admired disorder "[97-cellini] and mixed luxuriousness peculiar to [artists]342-artists , with [its]341-the lofty and elegant room heavily drooping velvet curtains , its glimpses of white marble busts and broken columns , its flash and fragrance of flowers that bloomed in a tiny conservatory opening out from [the studio]343-the studio and leading to [the garden]315-the garden , where a fountain bubbled melodiously - all this pleased [me]0-i and gave [me]0-i a curious , yet most welcome , sense of absolute rest . [Cellini]97-cellini [himself]97-cellini had a fascination for [me]0-i , for exactly the same reason . As an example of this , [I]0-i remember escaping from [Mrs. Everard]93-amy on one occasion , and hurrying to [the most secluded part of [the garden]315-the garden]345-the most secluded part of the garden , in order to walk up and down alone in an endeavour to calm an attack of nervous agitation which had suddenly seized [me]0-i . While thus pacing about in feverish restlessness , [I]0-i saw [Cellini]97-cellini approaching , [his]97-cellini head bent as if in thought , and [his]97-cellini hands clasped behind [his]97-cellini back . As [he]97-cellini drew near [me]0-i , [he]97-cellini raised [his]97-cellini eyes - they were clear and darkly brilliant - [he]97-cellini regarded [me]0-i steadfastly with a kindly smile . Then lifting [his]97-cellini hat with the graceful reverence peculiar to [an Italian]347-an italian , [he]97-cellini passed on , saying no word . But the effect of [his]97-cellini momentary presence upon [me]0-i was remarkable - it was ELECTRIC . [I]0-i was no longer agitated . Calmed , soothed and almost happy , [I]0-i returned to [Mrs. Everard]93-amy , and entered into [her]93-amy plans for the day with so much alacrity that [she]93-amy was surprised and delighted .

" If [you]0-i go on like this , "[93-amy] [she]93-amy said , " [you]0-i will be perfectly well in a month . "[93-amy]

[I]0-i was utterly unable to account for the remedial influence [Raffaello Cellini]97-cellini 's presence had upon [me]0-i ; but such as it was [I]0-i could not but be grateful for the respite it gave [me]0-i from nervous suffering , and [my]0-i now daily visits to [[the artist]348-the artist 's studio]349-the artist 's studio were a pleasure and a privilege not to be foregone . Moreover , [I]0-i was never tired of looking at [his]97-cellini pictures . [His]97-cellini subjects were all original , and some of them were very weird and fantastic . One large picture particularly attracted [me]0-i . It was entitled " [Lords of]95-lords of [our]1736-our Life and Death . "[97-cellini] Surrounded by rolling masses of cloud , some silver - crested , some shot through with red flame , was depicted [the World]7-the world , as a globe half in light , half in shade . Poised above it was [a great Angel , upon whose calm and noble face rested a mingled expression of deep sorrow , yearning pity , and infinite regret]350-a great angel , upon whose calm and noble face rested a mingled expression of deep sorrow , yearning pity , and infinite regret . Tears seemed to glitter on the drooping lashes of [this sweet yet stern Spirit]351-this sweet yet stern spirit ; and in [his]97-cellini strong right hand [he]97-cellini held a drawn sword - the sword of destruction - pointed forever downwards to the fated globe at [his]97-cellini feet . Beneath [this Angel]352-this angel and [the world [he]97-cellini dominated]353-the world he dominated was darkness - utter illimitable darkness . But above [him]97-cellini the clouds were torn asunder , and through a transparent veil of light golden mist , a face of surpassing beauty was seen - a face on which youth , health , hope , love , and ecstatic joy all shone with ineffable radiance . [It]354-it was [the personification of Life]355-the personification of life - not life as [we]356-we know it , brief and full of care - but [Life Immortal and Love Triumphant]96-life immortal and love triumphant . Often and often [I]0-i found [myself]0-i standing before this masterpiece of [Cellini]97-cellini 's genius , gazing at it , not only with admiration , but with a sense of actual comfort . One afternoon , while resting in [my]0-i favourite low chair opposite the picture , [I]0-i roused [myself]0-i from a reverie , and turning to [the artist]348-the artist , who was showing some water - colour sketches to [Mrs. Everard]93-amy , [I]0-i said abruptly :

" Did [you]348-the artist imagine that face of [the Angel of Life]1737-the angel of life , [Signor Cellini]97-cellini , or had [you]348-the artist a model to copy from ? "[0-i]

[He]348-the artist looked at [me]0-i and smiled .

" It is a moderately good portrait of an existing original , "[348-the artist] [he]348-the artist said .

" [A woman]1738-a woman 's face then , [I]348-the artist suppose ? How very beautiful [she]1738-a woman must be ! "[348-the artist]

" Actual beauty is sexless , "[348-the artist] [he]348-the artist replied , and was silent . The expression of [his]348-the artist face had become abstracted and dreamy , and [he]348-the artist turned over the sketches for [Mrs. Everard]93-amy with an air which showed [his]348-the artist thoughts to be far away from [his]348-the artist occupation .

" And [the Death Angel]1739-the death angel ? "[0-i] [I]0-i went on . " Had [you]348-the artist [a model for that also]1740-a model for that also ? "[0-i]

This time a look of relief , almost of gladness , passed over [his]348-the artist features .

" No indeed , "[348-the artist] [he]348-the artist answered with ready frankness ; " that is entirely [my]348-the artist own creation . "[348-the artist]

[I]0-i was about to compliment [him]348-the artist on the grandeur and force of [his]348-the artist poetical fancy , when [he]348-the artist stopped [me]0-i by a slight gesture of [his]348-the artist hand .

" If [you]0-i really admire the picture , "[348-the artist] [he]348-the artist said , " pray do not say so . If it is in truth a work of art , let it speak to [you]0-i as art only , and spare [the poor workman who has called it into existence the shame of having to confess that it is not above human praise]1741-the poor workman who has called it into existence the shame of having to confess that it is not above human praise . The only true criticism of high art is silence - silence as grand as heaven itself . "[348-the artist]

[He]348-the artist spoke with energy , and [his]348-the artist dark eyes flashed . [Amy Mrs. Everard]93-amy looked at [him]348-the artist curiously .

" Say now ! "[93-amy] [she]93-amy exclaimed , with a ringing laugh , " are n't [you]348-the artist a little bit eccentric , [signor]1742-signor ? [You]348-the artist talk like [a long - haired prophet]1743-a long - haired prophet ! [I]93-amy never met [an artist before who could n't stand praise]1744-an artist before who could n't stand praise ; it is generally a matter of wonder to [me]93-amy to notice how much of that intoxicating sweet [they]1744-an artist before who could n't stand praise can swallow without reeling . But [you]348-the artist 're an exception , [I]93-amy must admit . [I]93-amy congratulate [you]348-the artist ! "[93-amy]

[Cellini]97-cellini bowed gaily in response to the half - friendly , half - mocking curtsey [she]93-amy gave [him]348-the artist , and , turning to [me]0-i again , said :

" [I]93-amy have a favour to ask of [you]0-i , [mademoiselle]1745-mademoiselle . Will [you]0-i sit to [me]93-amy for [your]0-i portrait ? "[93-amy]

" [I]0-i ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed , with astonishment . " [Signor Cellini]97-cellini , [I]0-i can not imagine why [you]348-the artist should wish so to waste [your]348-the artist valuable time . There is nothing in [my]0-i poor physiognomy worthy of [your]348-the artist briefest attention . "[0-i]

" [You]0-i must pardon [me]348-the artist , [mademoiselle]98-mademoiselle , "[348-the artist] [he]348-the artist replied gravely , " if [I]348-the artist presume to differ from [you]0-i . [I]348-the artist am exceedingly anxious to transfer [your]0-i features to [my]348-the artist canvas . [I]348-the artist am aware that [you]0-i are not in strong health , and that [your]0-i face has not that roundness and colour formerly habitual to it . But [I]348-the artist am not [an admirer of the milkmaid type of beauty]1746-an admirer of the milkmaid type of beauty . Everywhere [I]348-the artist seek for intelligence , for thought , for inward refinement - in short , mademoiselle , [you]0-i have the face of [one whom the inner soul]1747-one whom the inner soul consumes , and , as such , may [I]348-the artist plead again with [you]0-i to give [me]348-the artist a little of [your]0-i spare time ? [YOU]0-i WILL NOT REGRET IT , [I]348-the artist ASSURE [YOU]0-i . "[348-the artist]

These last words were uttered in a lower tone and with singular impressiveness . [I]0-i rose from [my]0-i seat and looked at [him]358-he steadily ; [he]358-he returned [me]0-i glance for glance , A strange thrill ran through [me]0-i , followed by that inexplicable sensation of absolute calm that [I]0-i had before experienced . [I]0-i smiled - [I]0-i could , not help smiling .

" [I]0-i will come to - morrow , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

" A thousand thanks , [mademoiselle]98-mademoiselle ! Can [you]358-he be here at noon ? "[0-i]

[I]0-i looked inquiringly at [Amy]93-amy , who clapped [her]93-amy hands with delighted enthusiasm .

" Of course ! Any time [you]358-he like , [signor]1742-signor . [We]360-we will arrange [our]360-we excursions so that [they]360-we shall not interfere with the sittings . " It will depend on its appearance when completed , "[358-he] [he]358-he replied , as [he]358-he threw open the doors of [the studio]343-the studio and bowed [us]360-we out with [his]358-he usual ceremonious politeness .

" Au revoir , [madame]1750-madame ! [A demain]1751-a demain , [mademoiselle]1745-mademoiselle ! "[358-he] and the violet velvet curtains of [the portiere]361-the portiere fell softly behind [us]360-we as [we]360-we made [our]360-we exit .

" Is there not something strange about [that young man]1753-that young man ? " Something fiendish or angelic , or a little of both qualities mixed up ? "[93-amy]

" [I]0-i think [he]1753-that young man is what [people]1754-people term PECULIAR , when [they]1754-people fail to understand the poetical vagaries of genius , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied . " [He]1753-that young man is certainly very uncommon . "[0-i]

" Well ! "[365-my friend] continued [[my]0-i friend]365-my friend meditatively , as [she]365-my friend contemplated [her]365-my friend pretty mignonne face and graceful figure in a long mirror placed attractively in a corner of [the hall through which [we]360-we were passing]366-the hall through which we were passing ; " all [I]365-my friend can say is that [I]365-my friend would n't let [him]1753-that young man paint [MY]365-my friend portrait if [he]1753-that young man were to ask ever so ! " [I]0-i thought [you]365-my friend liked [him]1753-that young man , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

" So [I]365-my friend do . So does [[my]365-my friend husband]1755-my husband . [He]1753-that young man 's awfully handsome and clever , and all that - but [his]1753-that young man conversation ! There now , [[my]365-my friend dear]1756-my dear , [you]1756-my dear must own [he]1753-that young man is slightly QUEER . Why , who but [a lunatic]1757-a lunatic would say that the only criticism of art is silence ? Is n't that utter rubbish ? "[365-my friend]

" The only TRUE criticism , "[0-i] [I]0-i corrected [her]367-her gently .

" Well , it 's all the same . How can there be any criticism at all in silence ? According to [his]1753-that young man idea when [we]1758-we admire anything very much [we]1758-we ought to go round with long faces and gags on [our]1758-we mouths . That would be entirely ridiculous ! And what was that dreadful thing [he]1753-that young man said to [you]1756-my dear ? "[365-my friend]

" [I]0-i do n't quite understand [you]367-her , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered ; " [I]0-i can not remember [his]1753-that young man saying anything dreadful . "[0-i]

" Oh , [I]93-amy have it now , "[93-amy] continued [Amy]93-amy with rapidity ; " it was awful ! [He]1753-that young man said [you]1756-my dear had the FACE OF ONE WHOM THE SOUL CONSUMES . What did [he]1753-that young man mean by it , [I]93-amy wonder ? "[93-amy]

[I]0-i made no answer ; but [I]0-i thought [I]0-i knew . [I]0-i changed the conversation as soon as possible , and [[my]0-i volatile American friend]368-my volatile american friend was soon absorbed in a discussion on dress and jewellery . That night was a blessed one for [me]0-i ; [I]0-i was free from all suffering , and slept as calmly as [a child]369-a child , while in [my]0-i dreams the face of [Cellini]97-cellini 's " Angel of life "[97-cellini] smiled at [me]0-i , and seemed to suggest peace .

CHAPTER II .

[THE MYSTERIOUS POTION]370-the mysterious potion .

The next day , punctually at noon , according to [my]0-i promise , [I]0-i entered [the studio]343-the studio . [I]0-i was alone , for [Amy]93-amy , after some qualms of conscience respecting chaperonage , propriety , and [Mrs. Grundy]99-mrs. grundy , had yielded to [my]0-i entreaties and gone for a drive with [some friends]372-some friends . In spite of the fears [she]93-amy began to entertain concerning the Mephistophelian character of [Raffaello Cellini]97-cellini , there was one thing of which both [she]93-amy and [I]0-i felt morally certain : namely , that [no truer or more honourable gentleman]373-no truer or more honourable gentleman than [he]97-cellini ever walked on [the earth]374-the earth . Under [his]97-cellini protection [the loveliest and loneliest woman that ever lived]375-the loveliest and loneliest woman that ever lived would have been perfectly safe - as safe as though [she]375-the loveliest and loneliest woman that ever lived were shut up , like the princess in the fairy - tale , in [a brazen tower]376-a brazen tower , of which only an undiscoverable serpent possessed the key . When [I]0-i arrived , [the rooms]377-the rooms were deserted , save for the presence of a magnificent Newfoundland dog , who , as [I]0-i entered , rose , and shaking [his]97-cellini shaggy body , sat down before [me]0-i and offered [me]0-i [his]97-cellini huge paw , wagging [his]97-cellini tail in the most friendly manner all the while , [I]0-i at once responded to [his]97-cellini cordial greeting , and as [I]0-i stroked [his]97-cellini noble head , [I]0-i wondered where the animal had come from ; for though - [we]378-we had visited [[Signor Cellini]97-cellini 's studio]379-signor cellini 's studio every day , there had been no sign or mention of [this stately , brown - eyed , four - footed companion]380-this stately , brown - eyed , four - footed companion . [I]0-i seated [myself]0-i , and the dog immediately lay down at [my]0-i feet , every now and then looking up at [me]0-i with an affectionate glance and a renewed wagging of [his]97-cellini tail . Glancing round [the well - known room]381-the well - known room , [I]0-i noticed that the picture [I]0-i admired so much was veiled by a curtain of Oriental stuff , in which were embroidered threads of gold mingled with silks of various brilliant hues . On [the working easel]382-the working easel was a large square canvas , already prepared , as [I]0-i supposed , for [my]0-i features to be traced thereon . It was an exceedingly warm morning , and though the windows as well as the glass doors of [the conservatory]383-the conservatory were wide open , [I]0-i found the air of [the studio]343-the studio very oppressive . [I]0-i perceived on the table a finely - wrought decanter of Venetian glass , in which clear water sparkled temptingly . Rising from [my]0-i chair , [I]0-i took an antique silver goblet from the mantelpiece , filled it with the cool fluid , and was about to drink , when the cup was suddenly snatched from [my]0-i hands , and the voice of [Cellini]97-cellini , changed from its usual softness to a tone both imperious and commanding , startled [me]0-i .

" Do not drink that , "[97-cellini] [he]97-cellini said ; " [you]0-i must not ! [You]0-i dare not ! [I]97-cellini forbid [you]0-i ! "[97-cellini]

[I]0-i looked up at [him]97-cellini in mute astonishment . [His]97-cellini face was very pale , and [his]97-cellini large dark eyes shone with suppressed excitement . Slowly [my]0-i self - possession returned to [me]0-i , and [I]0-i said calmly :

" [YOU]97-cellini forbid [me]0-i , [signor]1742-signor ? Surely [you]1742-signor forget [yourself]1742-signor . What harm have [I]0-i done in helping [myself]0-i to a simple glass of water in [[your]1742-signor studio]1760-your studio ? [You]1742-signor are not usually so inhospitable . "[0-i]

While [I]0-i spoke [his]97-cellini manner changed , the colour returned to [his]97-cellini face , and [his]97-cellini eyes softened - [he]97-cellini smiled .

" Forgive [me]97-cellini , [mademoiselle]98-mademoiselle , for [my]97-cellini brusquerie . It is true [I]97-cellini forgot [myself]97-cellini for a moment . But [you]0-i were in danger , and - - "[97-cellini]

" In danger ! "[0-i] [I]0-i exclaimed incredulously .

" Yes , mademoiselle . This , "[97-cellini] and [he]97-cellini held up the Venetian decanter to the light , " is not water simply . If [you]0-i will observe it now with the sunshine beating full against it , [I]97-cellini think [you]0-i will perceive peculiarities in it that will assure [you]0-i of [my]97-cellini veracity . "[97-cellini]

[I]0-i looked as [he]97-cellini bade [me]0-i , and saw , to [my]0-i surprise , that the fluid was never actually still for a second . A sort of internal bubbling seemed to work in its centre , and curious specks and lines of crimson and gold flashed through it from time to time .

" What is it ? "[0-i] [I]0-i asked ; adding with a half - smile , " Are [you]97-cellini [the possessor of [a specimen of the far - famed Aqua Tofana]1762-a specimen of the far - famed aqua tofana]1761-the possessor of a specimen of the far - famed aqua tofana ? "[0-i]

[Cellini]97-cellini placed the decanter carefully on a shelf , and [I]0-i noticed that [he]97-cellini chose a particular spot for it , where the rays of the sun could fall perpendicularly upon the vessel containing it . Then turning to [me]0-i , [he]97-cellini replied :

" Aqua Tofana , mademoiselle , is a deadly poison , known to [the ancients]1763-the ancients and also to [many learned chemists of]1764-many learned chemists of [our]1765-our day . It is a clear and colourless liquid , but it is absolutely still - as still as a stagnant pool . What [I]97-cellini have just shown [you]0-i is not poison , but quite the reverse . [I]97-cellini will prove this to [you]0-i at once . "[97-cellini] And taking a tiny liqueur glass from a side table , [he]97-cellini filled it with the strange fluid and drank it off , carefully replacing the stopper in the decanter .

" But , [Signor Cellini]97-cellini , "[0-i] [I]0-i urged , " if it is so harmless , why did [you]97-cellini forbid [my]0-i tasting it ? Why did [you]97-cellini say there was danger for [me]0-i when [I]0-i was about to drink it ? "[0-i]

" Because , [mademoiselle]98-mademoiselle , for [YOU]0-i it would be dangerous . [Your]0-i health is weak , [your]0-i nerves unstrung . That elixir is a powerful vivifying tonic , acting with great rapidity on the entire system , and rushing through the veins with the swiftness of ELECTRICITY . [I]97-cellini am accustomed to it ; it is [my]97-cellini daily medicine . But [I]97-cellini was brought to it by slow , and almost imperceptible degrees . A single teaspoonful of that fluid , mademoiselle , administered to [anyone not prepared to receive it]1766-anyone not prepared to receive it , would be instant death , though its actual use is to vivify and strengthen human life . [You]0-i understand now why [I]97-cellini said [you]0-i were in danger ? "[97-cellini]

" [I]0-i understand , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied , though in sober truth [I]0-i was mystified and puzzled .

" And [you]97-cellini forgive [my]97-cellini seeming rudeness ? "[97-cellini]

" Oh , certainly ! But [you]97-cellini have aroused [my]97-cellini curiosity . [I]97-cellini should like to know more about this strange medicine of [yours]97-cellini . "[97-cellini]

" [You]0-i shall know more if [you]0-i wish , "[97-cellini] said [Cellini]97-cellini , [his]97-cellini usual equable humour and good spirits now quite restored . " [You]0-i shall know everything ; but not to - day . [We]1767-we have too little time . [I]97-cellini have not yet commenced [your]0-i picture . And [I]97-cellini forgot - [you]0-i were thirsty , and [I]97-cellini was , as [you]0-i said , inhospitable . [You]0-i must permit [me]97-cellini to repair [my]97-cellini fault . "[97-cellini]

And with a courteous salute [he]97-cellini left [the room]385-the room , to return almost immediately with a tumbler full of some fragrant , golden - coloured liquid , in which lumps of ice glittered refreshingly . A few loose rose - leaves were scattered on the top of this dainty - looking beverage .

" [You]0-i may enjoy this without fear , "[97-cellini] said [he]97-cellini , smiling ; " it will do [you]0-i good . It is an Eastern wine , unknown to trade , and therefore untampered with . [I]97-cellini see [you]0-i are looking at the rose - leaves on the surface . That is a Persian custom , and [I]97-cellini think a pretty one . They float away from [your]0-i lips in the action of drinking , and therefore they are no obstacle . "[97-cellini]

[I]0-i tasted the wine and found it delicious , soft and mellow as summer moonlight . While [I]0-i sipped it the big Newfoundland , who had stretched [himself]97-cellini in a couchant posture on the hearth - rug ever since [Cellini]97-cellini had first entered [the room]385-the room , rose and walked majestically to [my]0-i side and rubbed [his]97-cellini head caressingly against the folds of [my]0-i dress .

" [Leo]100-leo has made [friends]1768-friends with [you]0-i , [I]97-cellini see , "[97-cellini] said [Cellini]97-cellini . " [You]0-i should take that as a great compliment , for [he]100-leo is most particular in [his]100-leo choice of acquaintance , and most steadfast when [he]100-leo has once made up [his]100-leo mind . [He]100-leo has more decision of character than [many a statesman]1769-many a statesman . "[97-cellini]

" How is it [we]1770-we have never seen [him]100-leo before ? "[0-i] [I]0-i inquired . " [You]0-i never told [us]1770-we [you]0-i had such [a splendid companion]1771-a splendid companion . "[0-i]

" [I]348-the artist am not [[his]100-leo master]1772-his master , "[348-the artist] replied [the artist]348-the artist . " [He]100-leo only favours [me]348-the artist with a visit occasionally . [He]100-leo arrived from [Paris]5-paris last night , and came straight [here]1773-here , sure of [his]100-leo welcome . [He]100-leo does not confide [his]100-leo plans to [me]348-the artist , but [I]348-the artist suppose [he]100-leo will return to [[his]100-leo home]1774-his home when [he]100-leo thinks it advisable . [He]100-leo knows [his]100-leo own business best . "[348-the artist]

[I]0-i laughed .

" What [a clever dog]1775-a clever dog ! Does [he]100-leo journey on foot , or does [he]100-leo take [the train]1776-the train ? "[97-cellini]

" [I]0-i believe [he]100-leo generally patronizes [the railway]1777-the railway . [All the officials]1778-all the officials know [him]100-leo , and [he]100-leo gets into [[the guard]1779-the guard 's van]1780-the guard 's van as a matter of course . Sometimes [he]100-leo will alight at [a station en route]1781-a station en route , and walk the rest of the way . But if [he]100-leo is lazily inclined , [he]100-leo does not stir till [the train]1776-the train reaches its destination . At the end of every six months or so , [the railway authorities]1783-the railway authorities send the bill of [Leo]100-leo 's journeyings in to [[his]100-leo master]1772-his master , when it is always settled without difficulty . "[0-i]

" And who IS [[his]100-leo master]1772-his master ? "[0-i] [I]0-i ventured to ask .

[Cellini]97-cellini 's face grew serious and absorbed , and [his]97-cellini eyes were full of grave contemplation as [he]97-cellini answered :

" [[His]100-leo master]1772-his master , mademoiselle , is [[MY]388-he master]1787-my master - one who among [men]273-men , is supremely intelligent ; among [teachers]271-teachers , absolutely unselfish ; among [thinkers]1790-thinkers , purely impersonal ; among [friends]1768-friends , inflexibly faithful . To [him]1772-his master [I]388-he owe everything - even life itself . For [him]1772-his master no sacrifice , no extreme devotion would be too great , could [I]388-he hope thereby to show [my]388-he gratitude . But [he]1772-his master is as far above human thanks or human rewards as the sun is above [the sea]1792-the sea . Not here , not now , dare [I]388-he say to [him]1772-his master , [[MY]388-he FRIEND]365-my friend , BEHOLD HOW MUCH [I]388-he LOVE [THEE]1772-his master ! such language would be all too poor and unmeaning ; but hereafter - who knows ? - - "[388-he] and [he]388-he broke off abruptly with a half - sigh . Then , as if forcing [himself]388-he to change the tenor of [his]388-he thoughts , [he]388-he continued in a kind tone : " But , [mademoiselle]1745-mademoiselle , [I]388-he am wasting [your]1745-mademoiselle time , and am taking no advantage of the favour [you]1745-mademoiselle have shown [me]388-he by [your]1745-mademoiselle presence to - day . Will [you]1745-mademoiselle seat [yourself]1745-mademoiselle [here]1773-here ? "[388-he] and [he]388-he placed an elaborately carved oaken settee in one corner of [the studio]343-the studio , opposite [his]388-he own easel . " [I]388-he should be sorry to fatigue [you]0-i at all , "[388-he] [he]388-he went on ; " do [you]0-i care for reading ? "[388-he]

[I]0-i answered eagerly in the affirmative , and [he]388-he handed [me]0-i a volume bound in curiously embossed leather , and ornamented with silver clasps . It was entitled " Letters of [a Dead Musician]1796-a dead musician . "[388-he]

" [You]0-i will find clear gems of thought , passion , and feeling in this book , "[97-cellini] said [Cellini]97-cellini ; " and being [a musician]1797-a musician [yourself]0-i , [you]0-i will know how to appreciate them . [The writer]1798-the writer was one of [those geniuses whose work [the world]264-the world repays with ridicule and contempt]1799-those geniuses whose work the world repays with ridicule and contempt . There is no fate more enviable ! "[97-cellini]

[I]0-i looked at [the artist]348-the artist with some surprise as [I]0-i took the volume [he]388-he recommended , and seated [myself]0-i in the position [he]388-he indicated ; and while [he]388-he busied [himself]388-he in arranging the velvet curtains behind [me]0-i as a background , [I]0-i said :

" Do [you]388-he really consider it enviable , [Signor Cellini]97-cellini , to receive [the world]264-the world 's ridicule and contempt ? "[0-i]

" [I]388-he do indeed , "[388-he] [he]388-he replied , ' since it is a certain proof that [the world]264-the world does not understand [you]0-i . To achieve something that is above human comprehension , THAT is greatness . To have the serene sublimity of [the God - man Christ]101-god , and consent to be crucified by [a gibing world that was fated to be afterwards civilized and dominated by [His]388-he teachings]392-a gibing world that was fated to be afterwards civilized and dominated by his teachings , what can be more glorious ? ' Ah , mademoiselle , the knowledge of one 's own inner Self - Existence is a knowledge surpassing all the marvels of art and science ! "[388-he]

[Cellini]97-cellini spoke with enthusiasm , and [his]388-he countenance seemed illumined by the eloquence that warmed [his]388-he speech . [I]0-i listened with a sort of dreamy satisfaction ; the visual sensation of utter rest that [I]0-i always experienced in [this man]399-this man 's presence was upon [me]0-i , and [I]0-i watched [him]388-he with interest as [he]388-he drew with quick and facile touch the outline of [my]0-i features on [his]388-he canvas .

Gradually [he]388-he became more and more absorbed in [his]388-he work ; [he]388-he glanced at [me]0-i from time to time , but did not speak , and [his]388-he pencil worked rapidly . [I]0-i turned over the " Letters of [a Dead Musician]1796-a dead musician "[388-he] with some curiosity . Several passages struck [me]0-i as being remarkable for their originality and depth of thought ; but what particularly impressed [me]0-i as [I]0-i read on , was the tone of absolute joy and contentment that seemed to light up every page . There were no wailings over disappointed ambition , no regrets for the past , no complaints , no criticism , no word for or against the brothers of [his]388-he art ; everything was treated from a lofty standpoint of splendid equality , save when [the writer]1798-the writer spoke of [himself]1798-the writer , and then [he]1798-the writer became the humblest of [the humble]401-the humble , yet never abject , and always happy .

" O Music ! "[388-he] [he]388-he wrote , " Music , [thou]1803-thou Sweetest Spirit of all that serve [God]101-god , what have [I]388-he done that [thou]1803-thou shouldst so often visit [me]388-he ? It is not well , O [thou]1803-thou Lofty and Divine One , that [thou]1803-thou shouldst stoop so low as to console [him]388-he who is the unworthiest of [all [thy]1803-thou servants]1804-all thy servants . For [I]388-he am too feeble to tell [the world]264-the world how soft is the sound of [thy]1803-thou rustling pinions , how tender is the sighing breath of [thy]1803-thou lips , how beyond all things glorious is the vibration of [thy]1803-thou lightest whisper ! Remain aloft , [thou]1803-thou Choicest Essence of the Creator 's Voice , remain in that pure and cloudless ether , where alone [thou]1803-thou art fitted to dwell . [My]388-he touch must desecrate [thee]1803-thou , [my]388-he voice affright [thee]1803-thou . [Meeting Cellini]97-cellini 's glance as [I]0-i finished reading these lines , [I]0-i asked :

" How did [he]1807-the author of this book die ? "[0-i] [I]0-i inquired .

" [He]1807-the author of this book was playing the organ in [one of [the great churches of [Rome]6-rome]1814-the great churches of rome]1813-one of the great churches of rome on the day of the Feast of [the Virgin]1815-the virgin . " The music was wonderful , startling , triumphant - ever rising in power and majesty to a magnificent finale , when suddenly a slight crash was heard ; the organ ceased abruptly , [the singers]1817-the singers broke off . [The musician]1818-the musician was dead . [I]0-i speculated vaguely on the meaning of these last words , but [I]0-i felt disinclined to ask any more questions , and [Cellini]97-cellini , probably seeing this , worked on at [his]97-cellini sketch without further converse . [My]0-i eyes were growing heavy , and the printed words in the " Dead Musician 's Letters "[97-cellini] danced before [my]0-i sight like active little black demons with thin waving arms and legs . A curious yet not unpleasant drowsiness stole over [me]0-i , in which [I]0-i heard the humming of the bees at the open window , the singing of the birds , and the voices of [people]1754-people in [the hotel gardens]404-the hotel gardens , all united in one continuous murmur that seemed a long way off . [I]0-i saw the sunshine and the shadow - [I]0-i saw the majestic Leo stretched full length near the easel , and the slight supple form of [Raffaello Cellini]97-cellini standing out in bold outline against the light ; yet all seemed shifting and mingling strangely into a sort of wide radiance in which there was nothing but varying tints of colour . [I]0-i rubbed [my]0-i eyes violently , and started to [my]0-i feet at the sound of [the artist]348-the artist 's voice .

" [I]348-the artist have tried [your]0-i patience enough for to - day , "[348-the artist] [he]348-the artist said , and [his]348-the artist words sounded muffled , as though they were being spoken through , a thick wall . [I]0-i stood before [him]348-the artist mechanically , still holding the book [he]348-the artist had lent [me]0-i clasped in [my]0-i hand . [I]0-i trembled . Was not that picture veiled ? [I]0-i looked - there was no curtain at all , and the faces of [the two Angels]408-the two angels shone out of the canvas with intense brilliancy ! Strange to say , [I]0-i felt no surprise at this circumstance , which , had it occurred a moment previously , would have unquestionably astonished and perhaps alarmed [me]0-i . [I]0-i gazed steadfastly at the painting , and replied , half smiling :

" [I]0-i should be indeed ' far gone , ' as the saying is , if [I]0-i could not see that , [signor]1742-signor ! It is truly [your]1742-signor masterpiece . Why have [you]1742-signor never exhibited it ? "[0-i]

" [I]0-i think [I]0-i had a parting word to give [you]409-he , "[0-i] [I]0-i said at last , meeting [his]409-he gaze frankly ; " but [I]0-i seem to have forgotten what it was . "[0-i] [Cellini]97-cellini smiled gravely .

[He]409-he bent [his]409-he head reverentially .

" Merci mille fois , mademoiselle ! [Dieu vous garde - vous aussi . Au revoir]1831-dieu vous garde - vous aussi . au revoir . "[409-he]

And clasping [my]0-i hand with a light yet friendly pressure , [he]409-he closed the door of [[his]409-he room]411-his room behind [me]0-i . Once alone in [the passage]412-the passage , the sense of high elation and contentment that had just possessed [me]0-i began gradually to decrease . [I]0-i had not become actually dispirited , but a languid feeling of weariness oppressed [me]0-i , and [my]0-i limbs ached as though [I]0-i had walked incessantly for many miles . [I]0-i went straight to [[my]0-i own room]413-my own room . [I]0-i consulted [my]0-i watch ; it was half - past one , the hour at which [the hotel luncheon]414-the hotel luncheon was usually served . [Mrs. Everard]93-amy had evidently not returned from [her]93-amy drive . [I]0-i did not care to attend the table d'hote alone ; besides , [I]0-i had no inclination to eat . [I]0-i drew down the window - blinds to shut out the brilliancy of the beautiful Southern sunlight , and throwing [myself]0-i on [my]0-i bed [I]0-i determined to rest quietly till [Amy]93-amy came back . [I]0-i had brought the " Letters of [a Dead Musician]1796-a dead musician "[97-cellini] away with [me]0-i from [[Cellini]97-cellini 's studio]340-cellini 's studio , and [I]0-i began to read , intending to keep [myself]0-i awake by this means . But [I]0-i found [I]0-i could not fix [my]0-i attention on the page , nor could [I]0-i think at all connectedly . Little by little [my]0-i eyelids closed ; the book dropped from [my]0-i nerveless hand ; and in a few minutes [I]0-i was in a deep and tranquil slumber .

CHAPTER III .

THREE VISIONS .

Roses , roses ! An interminable chain of these royal blossoms , red and white , wreathed by the radiant fingers of small rainbow - winged creatures as airy as moonlight mist , as delicate as thistledown ! [They]416-they cluster round [me]0-i with smiling faces and eager eyes ; [they]416-they place the end of [their]416-they rose - garland in [my]0-i hand , and whisper , " FOLLOW ! "[416-they] Gladly [I]0-i obey , and hasten onward . Guiding [myself]0-i by the fragrant chain [I]0-i hold , [I]0-i pass through a labyrinth of trees , whose luxuriant branches quiver with the flight and song of birds . Then comes a sound of waters ; the riotous rushing of a torrent unchecked , that leaps sheer down from rocks a thousand feet high , thundering forth the praise of its own beauty as it tosses in the air triumphant crowns of silver spray . How the living diamonds within it shift , and change , and sparkle ! [Fain]103-fain would [I]0-i linger to watch this magnificence ; but the coil of roses still unwinds before [me]0-i , and the fairy voices still cry , " FOLLOW ! "[0-i] [I]0-i press on . The trees grow thicker ; the songs of the birds cease ; the light around [me]0-i grows pale and subdued . In the far distance [I]0-i see a golden crescent that seems suspended by some invisible thread in the air . Is it the young moon ? No ; for as [I]0-i gaze it breaks apart into a thousand points of vivid light like wandering stars . These meet ; they blaze into letters of fire . [I]0-i strain [my]0-i dazzled eyes to spell out their meaning . They form one word - [HELIOBAS]104-heliobas . [I]0-i read it . [I]0-i utter it aloud . The rose - chain breaks at [my]0-i feet , and disappears . The fairy voices die away on [my]0-i ear . There is utter silence , utter darkness , - save where that one NAME writes itself in burning gold on the blackness of the heavens .

The interior of [a vast cathedral]417-a vast cathedral is opened before [my]0-i gaze . The lofty white marble columns support a vaulted roof painted in fresco , from which are suspended a thousand lamps that emit a mild and steady effulgence . The great altar is illuminated ; [the priests]418-the priests , in glittering raiment , pace slowly to and fro . The large voice of the organ , murmuring to itself awhile , breaks forth in a shout of melody ; and [a boy]419-a boy 's clear , sonorous treble tones pierce the incense - laden air . " Credo ! "[419-a boy] - and the silver , trumpet - like notes fall from the immense height of [the building]420-the building like a bell ringing in a pure atmosphere - " Credo in unum Deum ; Patrem omni - potentum , factorem coeli et terrae , visibilium omnium et invisibilium . "[419-a boy]

[The cathedral]421-the cathedral echoes with answering voices ; and , involuntarily kneeling , [I]0-i follow the words of the grand chant . [I]0-i hear the music slacken ; the notes of rejoicing change to a sobbing and remorseful wail ; the organ shudders like a forest of pines in a tempest , " Crucifixus etiam pro nobis ; passus et sepultus est . "[423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two] A darkness grows up around [me]0-i ; [my]0-i senses swim . The music altogether ceases ; but a brilliant radiance streams through a side - door of [the church]422-the church , and [twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two , approach [me]0-i . [They]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two gaze at [me]0-i with joyous eyes . " Art [thou]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness also [one of [us]1834-us]1833-one of us ? "[423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two] [they]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two murmur ; then [they]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two pass onward to the altar , where again the lights are glimmering . [I]0-i watch [them]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two with eager interest ; [I]0-i hear [them]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two uplift [their]423-twenty maidens , clad in white and crowned with myrtle , pacing two by two fresh young voices in prayer and praise . [One of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness , leaves [[her]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness companions]425-her companions , and softly approaches [me]0-i . [She]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness holds a pencil and tablet in [her]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness hand .

" Write ! "[424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness] [she]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness says , in a thrilling whisper ; " and write quickly ! for whatsoever [thou]1835-thou shalt now inscribe is the clue to [thy]1835-thou destiny . "[424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness]

[I]0-i obey [her]424-one of them , whose deep blue eyes are full of lustrous tenderness mechanically , impelled not by [my]0-i own will , but by some unknown powerful force acting within and around [me]0-i . [I]0-i trace upon the tablet one word only ; it is a name that startles [me]0-i even while [I]0-i [myself]0-i write it down - [HELIOBAS]104-heliobas . Scarcely have [I]0-i written it when a thick white cloud veils [the cathedral]421-the cathedral from [my]0-i sight ; [the fair maiden]427-the fair maiden vanishes , and all is again still .

[I]0-i am listening to the accents of a grave melodious voice , which , from its slow and measured tones , would seem to be in the action of reading or reciting aloud . [I]0-i see [a small room sparely furnished]428-a small room sparely furnished , and at a table covered with books and manuscripts is seated [a man of noble features and commanding presence]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence . [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence is in the full prime of life ; [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence dark hair has no thread of silver to mar its luxuriance ; [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence face is unwrinkled ; [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence forehead unfurrowed by care ; [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence eyes , deeply sunk beneath [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence shelving brows , are of a singularly clear and penetrating blue , with an absorbed and watchful look in them , like the eyes of one accustomed to gaze far out at [sea]430-sea . [His]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence hand rests on the open pages of a massive volume ; [he]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence is reading , and [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence expression is intent and earnest - as if [he]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence were littering [his]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence own thoughts aloud , with the conviction and force of [an orator]431-an orator who knows the truth of which [he]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence speaks :

" [The Universe]1-the universe is upheld solely by the Law of Love . [A majestic invisible Protectorate]1836-a majestic invisible protectorate governs the winds , the tides , the incoming and outgoing of the seasons , the birth of the flowers , the growth of forests , the outpourings of the sunlight , the silent glittering of the stars . A wide illimitable Beneficence embraces all creation . A vast Eternal Pity exists for all sorrow , all sin . [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence who first swung [the planets]1837-the planets in the air , and bade [them]1837-the planets revolve till Time shall be no more - [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence , the Fountain - Head of Absolute Perfection , is no deaf , blind , capricious , or remorseless Being . To [Him]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence the death of the smallest singing - bird is as great or as little as the death of [a world 's emperor]1838-a world 's emperor . For [Him]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence the timeless withering of an innocent flower is as pitiful as the decay of [a mighty nation]1839-a mighty nation . [An infant]1840-an infant 's first prayer to [Him]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence is heard with as tender a patience as the united petitions of [thousands of [worshippers]1842-worshippers]1841-thousands of worshippers . For in everything and around everything , from the sun to a grain of sand , [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence hath a portion , small or great , of [His]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence own most Perfect Existence . Should [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence hate [His]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence Creation , [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence must perforce hate [Himself]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence ; and that Love should hate Love is an impossibility . Therefore [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence loves all [His]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence work ; and as Love , to be perfect , must contain Pity , Forgiveness , and Forbearance , so doth [He]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence pity , forgive , and forbear . Shall [a mere man]1843-a mere man deny [himself]1843-a mere man for the sake of [[his]1843-a mere man child]1844-his child or [friend]1845-friend ? and shall [the Infinite Love]105-the infinite love refuse to sacrifice itself - yea , even to as immense a humility as its greatness is immeasurable ? Shall [we]1846-we deny those merciful attributes to God which [we]1846-we acknowledge in [His]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence creature , [Man]282-man ? O [[my]429-a man of noble features and commanding presence Soul]1848-my soul , rejoice that [thou]1849-thou hast pierced the veil of the Beyond ; that [thou]1849-thou hast seen and known the Truth ! that to [thee]1849-thou is made clear the Reason of Life , and the Recompense of Death : yet while rejoicing , grieve that [thou]1849-thou art not fated to draw more than [a few souls]1850-a few souls to the comfort [thou]1849-thou hast thyself attained ! "[429-a man of noble features and commanding presence]

"[93-amy] and [she]93-amy read aloud :

" ' How mighty are [the Kingdoms of [the Air]8-the air]1898-the kingdoms of the air ! [Each one]1900-each one has a different duty to perform , yet all [their]1900-each one labours are lofty . But what a fate is [ours]1901-we on [this low earth]1902-this low earth ! [O Angelic Spirits]1904-o angelic spirits , what is there in the poor and shabby spectacle of human life to attract [your]1904-o angelic spirits mighty Intelligences ? " Do n't be afraid , "[0-i] [I]0-i said ; " [I]0-i 'll give back the book to [Signor Cellini]97-cellini to - morrow , and [I]0-i will tell [him]97-cellini that [you]1756-my dear do not like the idea of [my]0-i reading it , and that [I]0-i am going to study the Bible instead . Come now , [dear]1876-dear , do n't look cross ! "[0-i] and [I]0-i embraced [her]450-her warmly , for [I]0-i liked [her]450-her far too well to wish to offend [her]450-her . " Let [us]1918-our concentrate [our]1918-our attention on [our]1918-our finery for to - night , when a ' dense and brilliant multitude , ' not of air , but of [the ' earth earthy]1919-the ' earth earthy , ' will pass [us]1918-our under critical survey . [I]0-i assure [you]1756-my dear [I]0-i mean to make the best of [my]0-i improved looks , as [I]0-i do n't believe they will last . [I]0-i dare say [I]0-i shall be the ' sick nun ' that [you]1756-my dear termed [me]0-i again to - morrow . "[0-i]

" [I]365-my friend hope not , dearest , "[365-my friend] said [[my]0-i friend]365-my friend kindly , returning [my]0-i caress and forgetting [her]450-her momentary ill - humour . " A jolly dance will do [you]1756-my dear good if [you]1756-my dear are careful to avoid over - exertion . But [you]1756-my dear are quite right , [we]1918-our must really fix [our]1918-our things ready for the evening , else [we]1918-our shall be all in a flurry at the last moment , and nothing riles [the Colonel]1857-the colonel so much as to see [women]441-women in a fuss . [I]365-my friend shall wear [my]365-my friend lace dress ; but it wants seeing to . Will [you]1756-my dear help [me]365-my friend ? "[365-my friend]

Readily assenting , [we]452-we were soon deep in the arrangement of the numberless little mysteries that make up [a woman]1738-a woman 's toilette ; and nothing but the most frivolous conversation ensued . But as [I]0-i assisted in the sorting of laces , jewels , and other dainty appendages of evening costume , [I]0-i was deep in earnest meditation . Reviewing in [my]0-i own mind the various sensations [I]0-i had experienced since [I]0-i had tasted that Eastern wine in [[Cellini]97-cellini 's studio]340-cellini 's studio , [I]0-i came to the conclusion that [he]97-cellini must have tried an experiment on [me]0-i with some foreign drug , of which [he]97-cellini alone knew the properties . Why [he]97-cellini should do this [I]0-i could not determine ; but that [he]97-cellini had done it [I]0-i was certain . Besides this , [I]0-i felt sure that [he]97-cellini personally exerted some influence upon [me]0-i - a soothing and calming influence [I]0-i was forced to admit - still , it could hardly be allowed to continue . To be under the control , however slight , of [one who was almost a stranger to [me]0-i]455-one who was almost a stranger to me , was , at the least , unnatural and unpleasant . [I]0-i was bound to ask [him]97-cellini a few plain questions . And , supposing [Mrs. Everard]93-amy were to speak to [him]97-cellini about [his]97-cellini being betrothed , and [he]97-cellini were to deny it , and afterwards were to turn round upon [me]0-i and ask what authority [I]0-i had for making such a statement , what should [I]0-i say ? Convict [myself]0-i of falsehood ? However , it was no use to puzzle over the solution of this difficulty till it positively presented itself . At any rate , [I]0-i determined [I]0-i would ask [him]97-cellini frankly , face to face , for some explanation of the strange emotions [I]0-i had felt ever since meeting [him]97-cellini ; and thus resolved , [I]0-i waited patiently for the evening .

CHAPTER IV .

A DANCE AND A PROMISE .

[[Our]456-our little French friend]457-our little french friend , [Madame Didier]107-madame didier , was not [a woman to do things by halves]458-a woman to do things by halves . [She]107-madame didier was one of those rare exceptions among [Parisian ladies]459-parisian ladies - [she]107-madame didier was [a perfectly happy wife]460-a perfectly happy wife ; nay , more , [she]107-madame didier was in love with [[her]107-madame didier own husband]461-her own husband , a fact which , considering the present state of society both in [France]9-france and [England]10-england , rendered [her]107-madame didier almost contemptible in the eyes of [all advanced thinkers]462-all advanced thinkers . [She]107-madame didier was plump and jolly in appearance ; round - eyed and brisk as [a lively robin]463-a lively robin . [[Her]107-madame didier husband]317-her husband , [a large , mild - faced placid man]465-a large , mild - faced placid man - " [mon petit mari]1922-mon petit mari , "[465-a large , mild - faced placid man] as [she]107-madame didier called [him]465-a large , mild - faced placid man - permitted [her]107-madame didier to have [her]107-madame didier own way in everything , and considered all [she]107-madame didier did as perfectly well done . Therefore , when [she]107-madame didier had proposed this informal dance at [the Hotel de L -]11-the hotel de l - - , [he]317-her husband made no objection , but entered into [her]107-madame didier plans with spirit ; and , what was far more important , opened [his]317-her husband purse readily to [her]107-madame didier demands for the necessary expenses . So nothing was stinted ; [the beautiful ballroom attached to [the hotel]320-the hotel]466-the beautiful ballroom attached to the hotel was thrown open , and lavishly decorated with flowers , fountains , and twinkling lights ; an awning extended from [its]466-the beautiful ballroom attached to the hotel windows right down [the avenue of dark ilex - trees]468-the avenue of dark ilex - trees , which were ornamented with Chinese lanterns ; an elegant supper was laid out in [the large dining - room]469-the large dining - room , and [the whole establishment]470-the whole establishment was en fete . The delicious strains of a Viennese band floated to [our]471-our ears as [Colonel Everard]92-colonel everard , [[his]92-colonel everard wife]322-his wife , and [myself]0-i descended the staircase on [our]471-our way to the scene of revelry ; and suggestions of fairyland were presented to [us]471-our in the graceful girlish forms , clad in light , diaphanous attire , that flitted here and there , or occasionally passed [us]471-our . [Colonel Everard]92-colonel everard marched proudly along with the military bearing that always distinguished [him]92-colonel everard , now and then glancing admiringly at [[his]92-colonel everard wife]322-his wife , who , indeed , looked [her]322-his wife very best . [Her]322-his wife dress was of the finest Brussels lace , looped over a skirt of the palest shell - pink satin ; deep crimson velvet roses clustered on [her]322-his wife breast , and nestled in [her]322-his wife rich hair ; a necklace of magnificent rubies clasped [her]322-his wife neck , and the same jewels glittered on [her]322-his wife round white arms . [Her]322-his wife eyes shone with pleasurable excitement , and the prettiest colour imaginable tinted [her]322-his wife delicate cheeks .

" When [an American woman]1923-an american woman is lovely , [she]1923-an american woman is very lovely , "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " [You]322-his wife will be [the belle of [the room]385-the room]1924-the belle of the room to - night , [Amy]93-amy ! "[0-i]

" Nonsense ! "[322-his wife] [she]322-his wife replied , well pleased , though , at [my]0-i remark . " [You]322-his wife must remember [I]322-his wife have a rival in [yourself]322-his wife . "[322-his wife]

[I]0-i shrugged [my]0-i shoulders incredulously .

" It is not like [you]322-his wife to be sarcastic , "[0-i] [I]0-i said . " [You]322-his wife know very well [I]0-i have the air of a resuscitated corpse . "[0-i]

[The Colonel]1857-the colonel wheeled round suddenly , and brought [us]475-us all up to a standstill before a great mirror .

" If [YOU]0-i are like a resuscitated corpse , [I]1857-the colonel 'll throw a hundred dollars into [the next mud - pond]1926-the next mud - pond , "[1857-the colonel] [he]1857-the colonel observed . " Look at [yourself]0-i . "[1857-the colonel]

[I]0-i looked , at first indifferently , and then with searching scrutiny . [I]0-i saw [a small , slender girl]476-a small , slender girl , clad in white , with a mass of gold hair twisted loosely up from [her]476-a small , slender girl neck , and fastened with a single star of diamonds . A superb garniture of natural lilies of [the valley]477-the valley was fastened on [this girl]478-this girl 's shoulder ; and , falling loosely across [her]476-a small , slender girl breast , lost itself in the trailing folds of [her]476-a small , slender girl gown . [She]476-a small , slender girl held a palm - leaf fan entirely covered with lilies of [the valley]477-the valley , and a girdle of the same flowers encircled [her]476-a small , slender girl waist . [Her]476-a small , slender girl face was serious , but contented ; [her]476-a small , slender girl eyes were bright , but with an intense and thoughtful lustre ; and [her]476-a small , slender girl cheeks were softly coloured , as though a west wind had blown freshly against them . There was nothing either attractive or repulsive about [her]476-a small , slender girl that [I]0-i could see ; and yet - [I]0-i turned away from the mirror hastily with a faint smile .

" The lilies form the best part of [my]0-i toilette , "[0-i] [I]0-i said .

" That they do , "[93-amy] asserted [Amy]93-amy , with emphasis . " They are the finest specimens [I]93-amy ever saw . " Come , let [us]480-us proceed , "[0-i] [I]0-i answered , with some abruptness . " [We]480-us are losing time . "[0-i]

In a few seconds more [we]480-us entered [the ballroom]481-the ballroom , and were met at once by [Madame Didier]107-madame didier , who , resplendent in black lace and diamonds , gave [us]480-us hearty greeting . [She]107-madame didier stared at [me]0-i with unaffected amazement .

" Mon dieu ! [We]480-us readily assented , and the usual assortment of dancing - [men of all ages and sizes]482-men of all ages and sizes was brought forward for [our]480-us inspection ; while [the Colonel]1857-the colonel , being introduced to [a beaming English girl of some seventeen summers]484-a beaming english girl of some seventeen summers , whirled [her]484-a beaming english girl of some seventeen summers at once into the merry maze of [dancers]485-dancers , who were spinning easily round to the lively melody of one of [Strauss]117-strauss 's most fascinating waltzes . Presently [I]0-i also found [myself]0-i circling [the room]385-the room with [an amiable young German , who ambled round with a certain amount of cleverness , considering that [he]487-an amiable young german , who ambled round with a certain amount of cleverness , considering that he was evidently ignorant of the actual waltz step was evidently ignorant of the actual waltz step]487-an amiable young german , who ambled round with a certain amount of cleverness , considering that he was evidently ignorant of the actual waltz step ; and [I]0-i caught a glimpse now and then of [Amy]93-amy 's rubies as [they]488-they flashed past [me]0-i in the dance - [she]93-amy was footing it merrily with [a handsome Austrian Hussar]118-a handsome austrian hussar . [The room]385-the room was pleasantly full - not too crowded for the movements of [the dancers]490-the dancers ; and the whole scene was exceedingly pretty and animated . [I]0-i had no lack of [partners]491-partners , and [I]0-i was surprised to find [myself]0-i so keenly alive to enjoyment , and so completely free from [my]0-i usual preoccupied condition of nervous misery [I]0-i looked everywhere for [Raffaello Cellini]97-cellini , but [he]97-cellini was not to be seen . The lilies that [I]0-i wore , which [he]97-cellini had sent [me]0-i , seemed quite unaffected by the heat and glare of the gaslight - not a leaf drooped , not a petal withered ; and their remarkable whiteness and fragrance elicited many admiring remarks from those with whom [I]0-i conversed . It was growing very late ; there were only two more waltzes before the final cotillon . [I]0-i was standing near the large open window of [the ballroom]481-the ballroom , conversing with [one of [[my]0-i recent partners]494-my recent partners]493-one of my recent partners , when a sudden inexplicable thrill shot through [me]0-i from head to foot . Instinctively [I]0-i turned , and saw [Cellini]97-cellini approaching . [He]97-cellini looked remarkably handsome , though [his]97-cellini face was pale and somewhat wearied in expression . [He]97-cellini was laughing and conversing gaily with [two ladies]495-two ladies , one of whom was [Mrs. Everard]93-amy ; and as [he]97-cellini came towards [me]0-i [he]97-cellini bowed courteously , saying :

" [I]97-cellini am too much honoured by the kindness mademoiselle has shown in not discarding [my]97-cellini poor flowers . "[97-cellini]

" They are lovely , "[0-i] [I]0-i replied simply ; " and [I]0-i am very much obliged to [you]97-cellini , [signor]1742-signor , for sending them to [me]0-i . "[0-i]

" And how fresh they keep ! "[93-amy] said [Amy]93-amy , burying [her]93-amy little nose in the fragrance of [my]0-i fan ; " yet they have been in the heat of [the room]385-the room all the evening . "[93-amy]

" [They]1931-they can not perish while [mademoiselle]98-mademoiselle wears them , "[97-cellini] said [Cellini]97-cellini gallantly . " [Her]98-mademoiselle breath is [their]1931-they life . "[97-cellini]

" Bravo ! "[93-amy] cried [Amy]93-amy , clapping [her]93-amy hands . " That is very prettily said , is n't it ? "[93-amy]

[I]0-i was silent . [I]0-i never could endure compliments . They are seldom sincere , and it gives [me]0-i no pleasure to be told lies , however prettily they may be worded . [Signor Cellini]97-cellini appeared to divine [my]0-i thoughts , for [he]97-cellini said in a lower tone :
